sprite.name: (Unused) Character
sprite.notes:
This sprite is the most stable version of all the Mario clones.
It creates a stationary Mario clone that will be shown one tile above the sprite's placement. The clone will not move; nonetheless, the Mario 'twinkle' animation works. Also, this clone can shoot fireballs if Mario has a Fire Flower. Other functions have to be tested. It seems the initial purpose of this sprite was to function as an entrance. Additionally, depending on the position of this sprite relative to an entrance, this Mario can sometimes be controlled instead of the one created by the entrance.

checkbox.title: Looks left
checkbox.comment:
Checked: Character looks left.
Unchecked: Character looks right.

list.title: Entrance type
list.comment: (S)0-255. Same list and order as normal entrances. Every value creates a character at its position. Compared to normal entrances, Mario will be positioned on top of the sprite's placement and not inside it. The 3D model is stationary and does not move.

list.title: Character
list.comment:
Value 0-3. Specifies which character will be spawned.
Values larger than 3 will CRASH the game.

checkbox.title: Place Behind Other Sprites
checkbox.comment: Changes the Z-order of the Goomba

list.title: Load-In Animation
list.comment: This value seems to affect how the Goomba reacts when it shows up. Jumping and Tumble will place it on the platform below where it was placed.

sprite.name: Paragoomba
sprite.notes: A Goomba with wings that follows Mario.

value.title: Triggering Event ID
value.comment: If Event Activated is set, the platform will be shown when this Event ID is activated.

checkbox.title: Bowser Boss Battle Platform
checkbox.comment: Instead of the normal model, a texture from boss_koopa_lift.arc will be used. Replacing this model will result in custom textures for the platform.

list.title: Starts as...
list.entry: Like it was thrown by a Lakitu

checkbox.title: Unknown Flag 8
checkbox.comment: Used in Ambush Stages. Causes a bugged attribute if the spiny is placed non-adjacent to ceiling terrain with this checked. Unknown purpose.

value.title: Triggering Event ID
value.comment: If Event Activated is set, the platform will be shown when this Event ID is activated.

value.title: Width (Buggy)
value.comment: 0-7 Value. Does not tile the center portion of the block. Will work just fine with 1-Tile blocks, though.

value.title: Triggering Event ID
value.comment: If Event Activated is set, the platform will be shown when this Event ID is activated.

value.title: Width (Buggy)
value.comment: 0-7 Value. Does not tile the center portion of the block. Will work just fine with 1-Tile blocks, though.

sprite.name: (Unused) Ac_Lift_ObjBg_HMove_Big
sprite.notes:
This sprite does not load. Settings are the same as in sprite 28. We're currently unsure why this sprite does not load.
Needs RE (reverse-engineering) data to figure out the issue.

sprite.name: (Unused) Stone Tower Block
sprite.notes: A confusing sprite which uses a special delay system. Pay attention that there is a special delay at the start which isn't set by nybble 7 or 8. If value 0-3 is used for nybble 6 of every block, they all will begin to move in their start direction without delay (at the same time) when they are loaded.

value.title: Triggering Event ID
value.comment: When this is deactivated, the block does not instantly dissapear. However, if it leaves the screen, it will not respawn.

list.title: Movement Direction / Start Delay
list.comment: Determines the start direction of the block. The block will return to its initial position. Values repeat after 0-3.

checkbox.title: Start Delay
checkbox.comment: If checked, the platform will wait 2 ticks of the level's clock before moving. After the initial movement has occurred, this becomes irrelevant.

value.title: Delay Before Going Right/Up
value.comment: Sets how long it will stop after moving right/up. Value: 2 ticks of the level's clock. Values are evenly spaced.

value.title: Delay Before Going Left/Down
value.comment: Sets how long it will stop after moving left/down. Value: 2 ticks of the level's clock. Values are evenly spaced.

value.title: Distance
value.comment: How many tiles the block will move before returning to its starting point.

list.title: Height
list.comment: Value + 1; minimum is 2

list.title: Width
list.comment: Value + 1; minimum is 2

value.title: Triggering Event ID
value.comment: If Event Activated is set, the platform will be shown when this Event ID is activated.

checkbox.title: Event Activated
checkbox.comment: Makes the platform hidden unless triggered by an event

checkbox.title: Bowser Boss Battle Platform
checkbox.comment: Instead of the normal model, a texture from boss_koopa_lift.arc will be used. Replacing this model will result in custom textures for the platform.

sprite.name: Star Coin
sprite.notes: (S) Possibly uses value 5 or value 8. 5 is 0, 1, 2...?

value.title: Target Event ID
value.comment: When the star coin is collected, this Event ID will be activated.

list.title: Non-Timed Event
list.comment: This sets whether the triggered event is timed or permanent.

sprite.name: Event Controller - Zone Enter
sprite.notes: Event IDs 1-33 are per-level, and not per zone or area. Using this will clear that flag and set it to start activated or deactivated.

value.title: Event ID
value.comment: This Event ID will be activated when the zone loads.

value.title: Time Activated
value.comment: This value only works if Zone Enter is set to Activate Event, and sets a duration that the Event ID will be activated for.

checkbox.title: Does Nothing/Self Destructs
checkbox.comment: Makes the sprite skip its function and delete itself.

sprite.name: Event Controller - "AND" (If X AND Y, do Z)
sprite.notes: This sprite works by allowing up to 4 Event IDs to be required to activate a single Event. Not all Event IDs must be set to a relevant value. You CAN leave events as '0'. Duplicating the same value into several slots is not recommended.

list.title: Usage Mode
list.comment: Determines if and how often the relevant Event IDs will be triggered. Events with values '0' (Single Use) or '1' (Multi-Use) will keep their status, unless deactivated/reactivated manually.
list.entry: Only while All Events are Active

sprite.name: Event Controller - "OR" (If X OR Y, do Z)
sprite.notes: This sprite allows up to 4 Events to trigger the same Event ID. Not all Event IDs must be set to a relevant value. You CAN leave events as '0'. Duplicating the same value into several slots is not recommended.

list.title: Usage Mode
list.comment: Determines if and how often the relevant Event IDs will be triggered. Events with values '0' (Single Use) or '1' (Multi-Use) will keep their status, unless deactivated/reactivated manually.
list.entry: Only while All Events are Active

sprite.name: (Unused) Event Controller - "RANDOM" (If X, do Y OR Z)
sprite.notes:
This event controller can cause one of the four random IDs to trigger if a relevant Event ID has been activated. You do not have to use all four Random ID slots, and you can use the same ID on multiple slots.

Example: ID A in slot 1, ID A in slot 2 and ID B in slot 3 will cause 2/3 chance of A being activated and 1/3 chance of B.

value.title: Triggering Event ID
value.comment: This event causes one of the four random IDs to trigger

list.title: Usage Mode
list.comment: Determines if and how often the relevant Event IDs will be triggered. Events with values '0' (Single Use) or '1' (Multi-Use) will keep their status, unless deactivated/reactivated manually.

list.title: Switch Mode
list.comment: Random ID is Activated or Deactivated based on this Value

sprite.name: Event Controller - Chainer (If X, do Y)
sprite.notes: This event controller links two events together. If the first Event ID is triggered, then the second Event ID will be activated/deactivated, depending on the mode. It's also possible to define a delay time. If the Delay is set to 0, the event will be activated instantly. If not, it will wait a specific amount of time before activating.

value.title: Triggering Event ID
value.comment: When this Event ID is activated, the target Event ID will be activated or deactivated (depending on the mode).

value.title: Target Event ID
value.comment:
When activated, this Event ID will be switched (activated or deactivated), depending on the chosen mode.

Note: Deactivating a deactivated event will activate it. Activating an already activated event will deactivate it.

value.title: Activation Delay
value.comment: If the delay is set to 0, the event will be activated instantly. If not, it will wait a specific amount of time before activating. Info: A value of 6 is approximately 1 second on the game's clock.

list.title: Usage Mode
list.comment: Determines if and how often the relevant Event IDs will be triggered. Events with values '0' (Single Use) or '1' (Multi-Use) will keep their status, unless deactivated/reactivated manually by another event.

list.title: Switch Mode
list.comment: If Delay is 0, the "after Delay" effect happens immediately.

sprite.name: Event Controller - "IF" (Uses Locations)
sprite.notes:
This event controller can activate a Target Event ID, if either a player or an enemy touches a predefined location. There are many additional settings for this controller that can tweak its behavior, for example requiring Mario to have a specific power-up status, or requiring him to be inside a location instead of just touching it.

Setting up the controller to deactivate the Event ID instead of activating it will also swap the effect of the controller, requiring Mario to leave a predefined location or to clear a predefined location of all enemies to trigger the event.

Note: Some sprites are not counted as enemies, for example the Spike Ball. 'Loose Coins', on the other hand, are treated as enemies.

Yoshi does not work or interact with this sprite.

value.title: Target Event ID
value.comment: This Event ID will be activated when the specified location is touched.

value.title: Mario Location ID
value.comment: This is the location where 'Mario Status' is checked.

checkbox.title: Ignore Mario Location
checkbox.comment: If this is checked, the controller will only care about the status of the enemies, ignoring if Mario is inside the location.

value.title: Enemy Location ID
value.comment: This is the location where 'Enemy Status' is checked.

checkbox.title: Ignore Enemy Location
checkbox.comment: If this is checked, the controller will only care about the status of Mario, ignoring if an enemy is inside the Location.

list.title: Mario Power-up
list.comment: Event will only be triggered if Mario's power-up matches the one specified here, or if this is set to 0.

list.title: Mario Status
list.comment:
0 - Event is only triggered if a player is inside the Mario location.

1 - Event is only triggered if a player is touching the ground while inside the Mario location.

2- Event is only triggered if a player is jumping or otherwise not touching the ground inside the Mario location. Measurements always correspond to the center of Mario's feet (lowest pixel).
list.entry: Touching the Ground in the Location
In the Air in the Location

list.title: Usage Mode
list.comment:
0 - Event is only triggered once, when the Mario Status and Enemy Status are satisfied

1 - Event is triggered each time the Mario Status and Enemy Status are satisfied, but does not revert to the opposite state unless forced to by another controller

2 - Event is only triggered while Mario Status and Enemy Status are satisfied.

list.title: Switch Mode
list.comment:
If this option is set to "Deactivates Target", the activation modes will be reversed - for example, Activation Mode 2 will deactivate the event while you're touching the location, and reactivate it when you leave.

Note on locations for Enemies that have "Deactivates Target" set: The opposite effect of the controller becomes active when Mario gets close enough to the sprite to load it into memory. The opposite effect of the controller is always active though. The event is deactivated while the enemy touches the location, and will reactivate when it leaves. As stated before, this special behavior is only valid for enemy-'deactivated' Locations.

sprite.name: Event Controller - Multi-Chainer (If X, do Y THROUGH Z)
sprite.notes: The activator will start running when 'Start Event ID' is activated. It will then activate/deactivate (depending on the mode) each Event ID from ('Start Event ID' + 1) to 'End Event ID' (including this one).

value.title: Start Event ID
value.comment: The activator will start running when this Event ID is triggered.

value.title: End Event ID
value.comment: The activator will trigger all Events from the start Event ID to this Event ID (including this one). The value entered here must be larger than the value entered for 'Start Event ID'

value.title: Delay
value.comment:
The activator will wait this amount of time between triggering each event.
Note: A value of '6' approximates to 1 second of the game's clock.

list.title: Usage Mode
list.comment:
Only while Start Event ID is active: When the Start Event ID is turned off, the Multi-Chainer deactivates each event in the run, factoring in the Delay value.

Tip: You can first trigger this sprite, then immediately deactivate it, with 1 set, to cause it to turn off all related events. There is no direct way to turn off targeted events without first enabling them, though.
list.entry: Only while Start Event ID is Active

sprite.name: "?" Switch (Orange)
sprite.notes: Please remember that 'Multi-Use' is slightly buggy if used with events.

value.title: Triggering Event ID
value.comment: If this ID is set, the switch will only show while this Event ID is activated. Slightly buggy if used with Multi-Use.

checkbox.title: Falls
checkbox.comment: If this is checked, the switch will be movable by environment stuff, such as dropping down when bricks below it are destroyed, or riding along a conveyor belt.

checkbox.title: Loads at Midway
checkbox.comment: If this is checked, the switch will only show if the level has been started from a midway point.

checkbox.title: No Music Interrupt
checkbox.comment: If this is checked, the music will not be interrupted when the switch is pressed.

list.title: Delay on Multi-Use
list.comment: This will set how long the switch takes to pop up after the timer expires on a Multi-Use switch.

checkbox.title: Upside-Down
checkbox.comment: If this is checked, the switch will be facing down. Upside-down switches cannot fall.

sprite.name: "P" Switch (Blue)
sprite.notes:
This switch has the additional effect of making all (empty) brick blocks into coins, all coins into (empty) brick blocks, and all blue coins (both tileset-based and sprite-based) appear. This functionality only works with the "Timed" version of the switch.
Note: Don't place this switch too close to 'dancing blocks'. They will change their appearance to 'dancing coins' (it doesn't matter what they contain), but they will keep collision data and attributes like normal blocks. The player can stand on such coins, but cannot collect them or get an item out of them.

Note: There is a BUG with this additional effect. The switch will also cause Tile God events that are set to become red blocks to become solid. Also, coins can turn into empty brick blocks and vice versa.

sprite.name: Lava Bubble
sprite.notes: This sprite needs lava underneath it to function properly. It jumps up to whatever height you place the sprite at (with a maximum of 15 blocks above the lava).

value.title: Delay Before Jumping
value.comment: Possibly in game seconds (ticks on the game's timer)

sprite.name: Thwomp
sprite.notes: Yoshi does not work or interact with this sprite.

list.title: Type
list.comment: Note: Value '2' (Always Falling, Doesn't get up again) will cause the Thwomp to fall indefinitely, destroying not only one line of (breakable) ground, but as many as needed until he disappears offscreen. If he hits solid ground, the 'falling' animation and sound effect will not stop. This will create a very unaesthetic and loud sound.

sprite.name: Super Thwomp
sprite.notes: Yoshi does not work or interact with this sprite.

list.title: Type
list.comment: Note: Value '2' (Always Falling, Doesn't get up again) will cause the Super Thwomp to fall indefinitely, destroying not only one line of (breakable) ground, but as many as needed until he disappears offscreen. If he hits solid ground, the 'falling' animation and sound effect will not stop. This will create a very unaesthetic and loud sound.

sprite.name: (Unused) Seesaw Platform
sprite.notes: This is an incomplete platform that functions like a seesaw. Usage is not recommended, as the texture used is incomplete. Otherwise, it functions well.

list.title: Tilt Distance
list.comment: This option determines the maximum amount the platform can be tilted while standing on it. Values are a bit similar to those from the 'length' category. Value 5 and above will cause Mario to slide from the platform if standing on it for too long. From values 6+, the platform can be tilted more than 90°. Exceptions are values 11 and 15 - they will produce stationary platforms. They can be useful if a custom platform with customizable texture and size is needed.

list.title: Width
list.comment: Value x 2 (in blocks). Value '0' has a width of 16.

list.title: Fall
list.comment: Changes speed and delay of the falling platform. Value '0' creates an instantaneous drop, and value '1' a slower descent.

value.title: Width
value.comment: Width 0 has broken rendering.

sprite.name: (Unused) 4 Auto-Rotating Platforms
sprite.notes: This platform is an incomplete model. It was going to be something like the "Reznor" wheel. It consists of four 6x1 platforms that are placed like on an (invisible) circle, which will rotate around its center automatically with a predefined speed. Radius r = 6.5 Blocks. Usage is not recommended, as the texture used is incomplete. Otherwise, it functions well.

checkbox.title: Clockwise
checkbox.comment: Rotates counter-clockwise if not checked.

sprite.name: Quicksand
sprite.notes:
A quicksand object, such as object 24 in Pa1_sabaku (Desert), is required to cause the sinking behavior. In this tileset, it's a clear object located right before the yellow block. It's object 107 in the Pa1_toride_sabaku (Desert Tower) tileset, and object 26 in Pa1_sabaku_chika (Desert Cave).

Note: Has same possible attributes listed like Water, Lava, Poison (Flat Top, Location ID, Place behind Layer 1 objects). Other attributes exist but do not work respectively do not make sense. Quicksand will probably always be placed automatically behind Layer 1.

checkbox.title: Flat Top
checkbox.comment:
Checking this removes the animated crest effect on the top portion of the sprite. Creates a 'square' look.
Note: Only use with a flat ceiling or else this will look strange.

value.title: Location ID
value.comment: Match with a location to set the area of this sprite.

value.title: Unknown Value 7
value.comment: No visible change

checkbox.title: Throw Backwards
checkbox.comment: Makes the Lakitu throw spinies backwards (instead of in the viewing direction).

checkbox.title: Spawn from the background
checkbox.comment: If set to 1, Lakitu flies in from the background instead of spawning from the side.

value.title: Unknown Value 12
value.comment: No visible change

sprite.name: (Unused) Rising Tilting Platform
sprite.notes: A platform imported from New Super Mario Bros. DS. Size is 1x7 blocks. The distance covered depends on two factors: Y-position and zone height. See 'Movement Distance'.

list.title: Movement Distance
list.comment: Determines the maximum distance this Platform will cover. Covers 'Travel Limit' distance at value '0'. After any set amount of time, the platform will start blinking two blocks before the 'Travel Limit' and disappear once the player gets off it. For values marked with an asterisk (*), Mario must leave the platform for the blinking to begin. When it starts blinking, the platform's disappearance can't be prevented.

checkbox.title: Invisible Collision Box
checkbox.comment: While strange, this value's function is clear: When the game loads the platform for the first time into view, and the player then leaves the screen, this value tells the game to remember the last position of the platform. It will then spawn an equally large collision box exactly over its last position. Mario cannot fall through this collision box, but he may pass through coming from below. I.e. when loading the platforms back to the original position, Mario is carried by the collision box, if he stands on it. This happens each time the platform leaves the screen. The bad thing is that Mario cannot activate more platforms when he stands exactly over their original position, where they spawned initially.

checkbox.title: Always Rising
checkbox.comment: Causes the platform to rise when Mario approaches. If unchecked, Mario must step on the platform to activate it.

list.title: Vertical Movement and Direction
list.comment:
Determines how the platform moves on the Y-axis. If the value is set to '0' or '2', the platform will rise up. With value '1', the platform will fall slowly. The platform stops only after it has reached the 'Travel Limit' line. At this position, an upward-moving platform will stop ; however, a downward-moving platform will move continuously if a value of '1' is used and the platform is positioned below the 'Travel Limit' line. If the platform is placed above the 'Travel Limit' line, it will automatically be moved to the 'Travel Limit' line (no matter which direction it is moving) when it becomes active. The 'Travel Limit' line is located 7.5 Blocks below the upper zone border.

This platform functions independently of scroll limits (therefore, the 'Travel Limit' ignores scroll limits).

sprite.name: Rising Tilt-Controlled Girder
sprite.notes: Use with sprite 281 (Rising Tilt-Controlled Girder Controller) for proper functionality.

checkbox.title: Place Above Other Sprites
checkbox.comment: Makes this sprite appear over others.

checkbox.title: Unknown Value 10
checkbox.comment: (S) 0-1. Probably changes the direction the platform will move when the Wiimote is tilted.

list.title: Hiding in Shell
list.comment: 1 - Is in shell form when the sprite is loaded, 2 - stays in shell but still hurts if run into while a shell, until stomped on.

checkbox.title: Allow the Koopa 1-Up Trick
checkbox.comment: If this is not checked, the classic Koopa 1-Up staircase trick is impossible to pull off.

checkbox.title: Place Behind Fence
checkbox.comment: Changes the sprite's Z-order.

checkbox.title: Empty Shell
checkbox.comment: If this is checked, a empty kickable shell is spawned instead of a Koopa Troopa.

value.title: Unknown Value 5
value.comment: 0, C (Uses C in 6-01 A1) No visible change

value.title: Unknown Value 6
value.comment: 0, 2-6 (3-05 A1), 8 (6-01 A1) No visible change

list.title: Start Direction
list.comment: Defines how the Koopa will move upon load.

list.title: Flying Start Position
list.comment: The path starts from this position relative to the location of the Koopa's placement. The path is 10 Blocks wide. Value '0': Koopa will fly 5 Blocks, then turn around and from now on fly the full 10 Blocks. Value '1': The Koopa will fly 10 Blocks and then turn around.

list.title: Movement Type
list.comment: Flying - Moves 10 tiles total

list.title: Color
list.note: Unknown differences between Green and Red.

value.title: Rendering Related
value.comment: Actually a pointless option. This option only affects the code that renders the sprite. Setting a value of 0 results in an automatic use of value 5. Furthermore, the value is automatically multiplied by 64. At 0 and 5, we get a value of 320. Treeki also thinks that this option could represent a counter. What this option actually does is control the blinking of the carrier platform. If the multiplied value is below 180 AND if the second bit of the nybble was used, the carrier platform will not be rendered. Otherwise, this option only has the ability to tweak the blinking of the carrier platform. One would have to play around with some values​​.

checkbox.title: No Rendering?
checkbox.comment: Selecting this option will trigger the effect described under 'Rendering Related'.

checkbox.title: Stays Off
checkbox.comment: Activating this will cause the platform to not react/move when Mario stands on it. The code hints that it should only prevent this platform from disappearing instead of freezing it altogether.

list.title: Activation Mode
list.comment: Determines when the platform will start moving. Value 1: All players have to stand on it or it will not start moving.
list.entry: Will Move ONLY with All Players

value.title: Width of the Collision Box
value.comment: Value + 6. This option is pretty crazy. It does not change the length of the platform, but instead the length of the (invisible) collision box attached. The collision box ensures that Mario does not fall through the platform. The collision box usually has the same size as the platform itself. The collision box and the platform have the same center point. Per value, the collision box will extend its length 1/2 blocks to the left and right. If you stand on this collision box but outside the platform, then it looks as if you are standing in midair.

list.title: Orientation
list.comment: It must be placed against something for it to appear.

value.title: Speed
value.comment: Makes the Boo move slightly faster if value 1 is used.

value.title: Unknown Value 11
value.comment: (S) 0-15. Does this have a purpose?

sprite.name: Spinning Firebar
sprite.notes: Yoshi can't safely jump on this enemy.

list.title: Base Size
list.comment: Block base. If two blocks wide, centers from the sprite's location. The base has no collision. You need to place object 1 from the Standard Suite behind it to create collision.

checkbox.title: Place Behind Fence
checkbox.comment: Changes the Z-order.

checkbox.title: Clockwise
checkbox.comment: Counter-clockwise if unchecked.

checkbox.title: Double Firebar
checkbox.comment: Causes the bar to extend in both directions.

list.title: Length
list.comment: Value + 2. One fireball = approx. 0.75 blocks.

sprite.name: Spiked Ball
sprite.notes: Yoshi can't safely jump on this enemy.

list.title: Acceleration
list.comment: This controls how quickly the ball will change direction upon hitting a wall.

sprite.name: Thick Fog
sprite.notes:
Can be placed with or without a location ID. Creates a thick rolling fog effect.

Could even support another nybble (10) with value 4, just like water does. This would allow to place the fog behind the main layer (NOT TESTED).

sprite.name: Pipe Piranha Plant - Right
sprite.notes: This sprite will not behave correctly if placed underwater - in order for its positioning to be correct, it must be placed one block away from the pipe's edge.

sprite.name: Pipe Piranha Plant - Left
sprite.notes: This sprite will not behave correctly if placed underwater - in order for its positioning to be correct, it must be placed one block away from the pipe's edge.

sprite.name: Pipe Fire Piranha Plant - Right
sprite.notes: This sprite will not behave correctly if placed underwater - in order for its positioning to be correct, it must be placed one block away from the pipe's edge.

sprite.name: Pipe Fire Piranha Plant - Left
sprite.notes: This sprite will not behave correctly if placed underwater - in order for its positioning to be correct, it must be placed one block away from the pipe's edge.

checkbox.title: Unknown Flag 11
checkbox.comment: Used in 5-04 A1, no visible change

checkbox.title: Upside-Down
checkbox.comment: Plant will hang from the ceiling if checked.

checkbox.title: Unknown Flag 11
checkbox.comment: Used in 5-04 A1, no visible change

checkbox.title: Upside-Down
checkbox.comment: Plant will hang from the ceiling if checked.

checkbox.title: Upside-Down
checkbox.comment: Plant will hang from the ceiling if checked.

checkbox.title: Upside-Down
checkbox.comment: Plant will hang from the ceiling if checked.

sprite.name: (Unused) Doomship Key
sprite.notes: No visible change with any values set, and it does not seem to be event related in any way. Collecting this key causes it to fly up past the top-left corner of the screen near the Star Coin inventory, but nothing changes. May relate to another unused sprite, but likely is useless without mods.

sprite.name: Bouncy Cloud
sprite.notes: Yoshi does not work or interact with this sprite.

checkbox.title: Larger
checkbox.comment: If checked, the cloud will be bigger.

sprite.name: (Unused) En_Helpos
sprite.notes: No code.

sprite.name: (Unused) Stone Tower Block with Spikes (Left)
sprite.notes: A confusing sprite which uses a special delay system. Pay attention that there is a special delay at the start which isn't set by nybble 7 or 8. If value 0-3 is used for nybble 6 of every block, they all will begin to move in their start direction without delay (at the same time) when they are loaded.

value.title: Triggering Event ID
value.comment: When this is deactivated, the block does not instantly dissapear. However, if it leaves the screen, it will not respawn.

list.title: Movement Direction / Start Delay
list.comment: Determines the start direction of the block. The block will return to its initial position. Values repeat after 0-3.

checkbox.title: Start Delay
checkbox.comment: If checked, the platform will wait 2 ticks of the level's clock before moving. After the initial movement has occurred, this becomes irrelevant.

value.title: Delay Before Going Right/Up
value.comment: Sets how long it will stop after moving right/up. Value: 2 ticks of the level's clock. Values are evenly spaced.

value.title: Delay Before Going Left/Down
value.comment: Sets how long it will stop after moving left/down. Value: 2 ticks of the level's clock. Values are evenly spaced.

value.title: Distance
value.comment: How many tiles the block will move before returning to its starting point.

list.title: Height
list.comment: Value + 1

list.title: Width
list.comment: Value + 1

sprite.name: (Unused) Trampoline Wall
sprite.notes: This sprite lacks finished textures and as such, is incomplete. Upon contact, Mario is thrust in the opposite direction.

list.title: Height
list.comment: Value + 1

sprite.name: (Unused) - En_Boyon
sprite.notes: No code.

sprite.name: (Unused) - En_Remocon_Torimochi
sprite.notes: No code. Name means "Remote Controlled Bird Trap"

sprite.name: Wind Physics and Sound
sprite.notes: Requires sprite 374 (Snow / Wind Visuals) to generate sandstorm graphics as in W2-4.

value.title: Time Active
value.comment: Amount of time that the wind is on

value.title: Time Deactive
value.comment: Amount of time that the wind is off

checkbox.title: Blows Left
checkbox.comment: Changes directions from blowing right to blowing left.

value.title: Movement ID
value.comment: Known matched sprites - 284 (Wind Physics Coins)

sprite.name: Autoscrolling Controller
sprite.notes: Does not work without a path. Please note that it's impossible to 'trick the screen' into leaving the zone due to autoscrolling.

value.title: Target Event ID
value.comment: When the autoscroller reaches its final path point, this Event ID is triggered.

value.title: Triggering Event ID
value.comment: When this Event ID is activated, the autoscroll will start. Deactivating the event will not stop the autoscroll.

value.title: Midway Start Node ID
value.comment: If the Midway Point has been activated, then the autoscroll will start from this node ID, and not from the first node.

list.title: Mode
list.comment: If set to 0, the screen will start scrolling when the event is activated. If set to 2, the only way to activate it is by pounding the Unused Arrow Block (sprite 321). If set to 3, the auto-scroll self-activates. Values 1 and 2 cause problems and the auto-scroll won't behave properly.

list.title: End Behavior
list.comment: Decides what will happen when the last node is hit. If set to 0, the scrolling will stop and the camera will put Mario in the center of the screen. If set to 1, the autoscroll will bounce back and forth between the starting and end nodes. If set to 2, the autoscroll will just stop. 4 seems to be nothing special, the screen will simply stop. Nintendo only uses 4. Also, try to experiment with other values and report your findings on the RVLution forums (http://rvlution.net).

value.title: "End Behavior" related: Wobbling Animation
value.comment: If End Behavior is set to 1, and this is set to 1, it will cause the screen to wobble back and forth in a short distance. "2" will make the wobbling faster. Anything past that seems to just stop the autoscroll.

value.title: Unknown Value 11
value.comment: The only valid values are 0 and 1; possibly specifies how the screen follows the path as sprite 159 specifies it for linked objects?

value.title: Path ID
value.comment: Sets the path the camera will follow while scrolling. The upper left corner of the Screen (relative to the sprite's placement) is the starting point for the path.

value.title: Missile Bill Limit
value.comment: Controls how many Missile Bills the cannon can send out at once. It will not shoot more than this number unless the existing ones are defeated or have left the screen.

value.title: Z-Order
value.comment: 0-7, used as 0-7 in W7-07. Controls Z-order of a Bullet Bill in relation to any Bill Blasters.

list.title: Height
list.comment: Value + 2

value.title: Missile Banzai Bill Limit
value.comment: Controls how many Missile Banzai Bills the cannon can send out at once. It will not shoot more than this number unless the existing ones are defeated or have left the screen.

value.title: Z-Order
value.comment: Same function as sprite 92 (Bill Blaster).

list.title: Unknown Value 9
list.comment: (S) 0-3. Value 15?

list.title: Direction
list.comment: (S) 0-15. Could have other functions.

value.title: Fire Delay
value.comment:
(S) 0-15. Determines the delay between firing two Banzai Bills.
0 = normal
1 = very long
2 = long
Please test more values and report them at RVLution.net .

checkbox.title: Homing
checkbox.comment: This checkbox works - but due to the Missile Banzai Bills' movement, it will look a little weird if used. 'Direction' will only determine the Banzai Bill's line of sight.

value.title: Value 12
value.comment: The Homing checkbox activates Value 1 for this option. More values are listed: (S) 0-15.

list.title: Platforms
list.comment: Changes the amount of platforms the Hammer Bro. will use. Defaults and maxes at 2. (S) 0-3.

list.title: Swing Arc
list.comment: No swing arc at 0. This value how large the swing arc is. It will swing (arc * 11.25) degrees in each direction per value.

list.title: Speed
list.comment: No movement at 0. These calues ​​assume a uniform radius. The greater the radius, the faster the rotation speed. The rate of increase per values is very small.

value.title: Pause Length
value.comment: Speed value that sets how long it rests at the end of its swing.

value.title: Unknown Value 10
value.comment: 0, 1, 2 - no visible change.

value.title: Rotation ID
value.comment: Sways matched Rotation Controlled items.

sprite.name: (Unused) Rotation Controlled Solid-On-Top Platform
sprite.notes: The name is 'En_Lift_Rotation_Full'. For this sprite to appear correctly, the width and height must be set to at least one block! The main difference with its twin Sprite 107 is its collision. This platform is only solid-on-top. However, with the default orientation, the solid edges are on the sides - therefore, you will need to rotate it 90 degrees in order to be useful. Or you can use the solid edges to wall-jump.

list.title: Z-Order
list.comment: Determines the Z-order value for the platform. Values 3+ are similar to 3.

value.title: Width
value.comment: In blocks. MUST BE AT LEAST one! Determines the width of the platform. Since this is only a 5-bit option, the values ​​for all 32 options ​​repeat.

value.title: Height
value.comment: In blocks. MUST BE AT LEAST one! Determines the height of the platform. Since this is only a 5-bit option, the values ​​for all 32 options ​​repeat.

value.title: Rotation ID
value.comment: Match to a Rotation Controller to make this sprite move. Works with both Spinning and Swaying.

list.title: Acceleration
list.comment: This controls how quickly the ball will change direction upon hitting a wall.

sprite.name: Pipe Enemy Generator
sprite.notes: Requires a pipe to function properly.

list.title: Spawn Mode
list.comment: Turn this on to change the rate that the enemies are created.

checkbox.title: Unknown Value 10
checkbox.comment: (S) 0-1; no visible change

value.title: Delay
value.comment: (S) Apparently is an 11-12 byte, 0-6, 8-B Won't swoop down immediately when it sees you - it'll make a brief pause before doing so.

list.title: Load-in Animation
list.comment: Value 2: The Bob-omb is placed under a random angle in a random spot inside a square of 3x3 blocks, the sprites placement it the middle block. It can't hurt Mario, nor can it be frozen or 'fired'. It's on top of layer 2 and 1, but behind Mario. No relation to value 12.

list.title: Possible Value 12
list.comment: (S) 0-1 and (S) 0-3, No visible change

checkbox.title: Always Active
checkbox.comment:
Check this to cause the platform generator to spawn platforms even when not onscreen. Spawned platforms also remain loaded when this is checked. When unchecked, going out of range of the spawner causes them to despawn.
Note: It seems there is no spawn limit for horizontal platforms (Left / Right), but vertical platforms (Up / Down) will eventually stop spawning if the player is too far away from the generator.

list.title: Direction
list.comment: Platforms spawn from the placement of the sprite.

value.title: Width of Platform
value.comment: Values under 2 are buggy. Platforms extend to the right of the sprite's placement.

checkbox.title: Possible Value 12
checkbox.comment: (S) 0-1, No visible change

sprite.name: Amp
sprite.notes: Yoshi can't safely jump on this enemy, nor can he eat it. However, Mario won't get electrocuted if Yoshi gets damaged by this enemy.

sprite.name: Pokey
sprite.notes: Height also affects what Yoshi lays when consumed whole.

list.title: Height
list.comment: Maximum value is 7. Values 8-15 are identical to values 0-7. Each piece (head or body) is 1x1 blocks.

value.title: Triggering Event ID
value.comment: If Event Activated is set, the platform will be shown when this Event ID is activated.

list.title: Speed
list.comment: Sprites 108 (Line Controlled Amps), 155 (Line Controlled Star Coin), 343 (Fuzzy), 402 (Line Controlled ?-Block), and 403 (Line Controlled Brick Block) have identical speeds.

checkbox.title: Starts Moving on Touch
checkbox.comment: If this option is checked, the platform will start moving once a player stands on it.

checkbox.title: Reverse
checkbox.comment: Causes the platform to move in the opposite direction (Left / Down)

checkbox.title: Place Behind Other Sprites
checkbox.comment: Technically a Z-order value, 0-15

value.title: Width
value.comment: Minimum is 2

sprite.name: (Unused) Rotation-Controlled Solid Platform
sprite.notes: "En_Lift_Rotation_Half". A Rotation Controlled block that works quite well. Flag x08 + x02 (x0A) (Unique Flag).

value.title: Width
value.comment: Value + 1, in blocks. Values repeat in groups of 32.

value.title: Rotation ID
value.comment: Works with both Swaying and Spinning.

sprite.name: Line Controlled Amp Spawner
sprite.notes:
Spawns Amps when placed (correctly) on a line object. They spawn from the sprite's placement.

Yoshi can't safely jump on this enemy, nor can he eat it. However, Mario won't get electrocuted if Yoshi gets damaged by this enemy.

list.title: Speed
list.comment: Sprites 106 (Line Controlled Moving Platform), 155 (Line Controlled Star Coin), 343 (Fuzzy), 402 (Line Controlled ?-Block), and 403 (Line Controlled Brick Block) have identical speeds.

checkbox.title: Reverse
checkbox.comment: Causes the amps to move in the opposite direction (Left / Up)

list.title: Number of Amps
list.comment: Value + 1, number of amps spawned

value.title: Delay Between Amp Spawns
value.comment: Amount of time before the next amp spawns.

checkbox.title: Place Behind Other Sprites
checkbox.comment: Appears behind other sprites. Example usage - make the amp load behind a platform riding on the same line.

sprite.name: Ball 'n' Chain
sprite.notes: 6x6 - centered

checkbox.title: Clockwise
checkbox.comment: Rotates counter-clockwise if unchecked.

list.title: Start Location
list.comment: From the center

value.title: Unknown Value 12
value.comment: (S) 0-15, Check for other values, it may be able to produce something other than sunlight. The name of this sprite is "En_Env", which implies that it may have more functions.

list.title: On Approach Action
list.comment: (S) 0-15. Determines the blooper's approach action when it meets Mario. If the value is 1, it simply floats around in the water as usual, without ambushing Mario.
list.entry: Shoots Up at 45° to the Right
Shoots Up at 45° to the Left

list.title: Start Direction
list.comment: Specifies the Blooper's initial direction. Then he follows Mario as far as he can.

list.title: On Approach Action
list.comment: (S) 0-15. Determines the Blooper Nanny's Approach Action when it meets Mario. If the value is 1, it simply floats around in the water as usual, without ambushing Mario.
list.entry: Shoots Up at 45° to the Right
Shoots Up at 45° to the Left

list.title: Start Direction
list.comment: Specifies the Blooper Nanny's initial Direction. Then he follows Mario as far as he can.

sprite.name: Cheep Cheep / Deep Cheep / Eep Cheep

checkbox.title: Swims Left
checkbox.comment: If checked, swims to the left. The fish will not swim backwards when you backtrack. If unchecked, the direction the Cheep Cheep swims first depends on the 'Type'. For Types 3, 4, 6 and 7, it swims to the right in general. All other types will cause the Cheep Cheeps to swim first in Mario's direction.

checkbox.title: Positioning Flag 2
checkbox.comment:
Treeki:
Setting Flag 2 and 4 for Nybble 4: This function will create a particular Y position picture of all the Cheep Cheeps, each frame. The 'Cheep Cheep Formation Spawner' that has generated the Cheep Cheeps will store this 'picture'.

checkbox.title: Positioning Flag 4
checkbox.comment:
Treeki:
Setting Flag 2 and 4 for Nybble 4: This function will create a particular Y position picture of all the Cheep Cheeps, each frame. The 'Cheep Cheep Formation Spawner' that has generated the Cheep Cheeps will store this 'picture'.

value.title: Positioning
value.comment:
Treeki also commented:
'Nybble 6 determines WHICH position is allocated to the fish. This option is only useful for the Cheep Cheep Formation Spawner (247), because 247 uses this nybble for all generated Cheep Cheeps. For everything else, this option seems to be pointless. When you use the two flags for a Cheep Cheep in Reggie!, the corresponding Cheep Cheep won't have 'parents' any more, so it will get some random data for the Y position and might go off the screen. So you can safely ignore this value.'

list.title: Swim Distance
list.comment: Value + 1 in blocks. Only valid for Cheep Cheeps with 'Type' 3 (Swims Left / Right). Distance is calculated from the sprite's placement in both directions.

list.title: Swim Speed
list.comment:
0-3. Values 3+ are identical to 3.
Note: Type-3 Cheep Cheeps (Swims Left / Right) have the same speed as values 1 and 2.

list.title: Type
list.comment:
Specifies the Swimming-'Type' that should be used for this Cheep Cheep. Deep Cheeps and Eep Cheeps only work in non-location water. Value 5 is unique. Type-5 Cheep Cheeps will look into the camera until Mario comes close. Furthermore, the direction will be ignored and the Cheep Cheep will always swim in the opposite direction, away from Mario, if Mario is close enough.

Values marked ​​with an asterisk (*) will ignore the speed value set and instead will always use value 1, no matter what is selected there. Also, all values ​​with (*) will let the Cheep Cheep swim in a wavy line (just as the Coin Cheep Cheep does).

The two values ​​with (**) follow exactly the same behavior as those marked with (*), the only difference is its speed. Cheep Cheeps affected will swim slightly faster, both vertical and horizontal.
list.entry: Cheep Cheep ("WaterWait"), Waits, Then Swims Straight**

value.title: 'Dodge' Event ID
value.comment:
This may look weird at first glance, but it seems as if this function should work. It definitely has to do with Type 3 (Swims Left / Right).
Treeki wrote this: 'LrSwim (Type 3) accepts an Event that will make the Cheep Cheep follow the player (turning state LrSwim into state LrSrcSwim)'. If it really works is a good question. Try it and report your findings on RVLution.net !

sprite.name: (Unused) Coin Cheep
sprite.notes: An ordinary Cheep Cheep with possibly the same properties, but swims in a wavy form (2 blocks high, starts half a block below the sprite. Goes down during two blocks (HEIGHT = -1), and then goes up during 2 blocks (HEIGHT = -0.5) and then repeats). Seems to be a replica of the Cheep Cheeps from New Super Mario Bros. (DS), which pull coins behind them. However, this behavior is not yet explored.

list.title: Swimming Direction
list.comment: Sets the direction. Values 3, 7, 11 and 15 always delete the Coin Cheep. No difference in non-location water.

checkbox.title: Waiting
checkbox.comment:
Value 1 is the same as 2-15.
If the value isn't 0, the Coin Cheep will behave like this: If Mario isn't close enough (more than 5 blocks away), the Coin Cheep stands still and looks at the camera. When Mario comes closer, the Coin Cheep starts moving to the left, IGNORING the direction set at nybble 5.

checkbox.title: Immune to Lava
checkbox.comment: Only used in 8-24 A2. If checked, the Dry Bones will not disappear if he touches lava.

sprite.name: Sprite Crashes Game - "En_Reverse"
sprite.notes: Broken Sprite - it will either CRASH the game or do nothing, since it tries to reference files which don't exist in the final game (tobira.bti Texture). Adding this Texture could enable the Sprite's (yet unknown) options.

sprite.name: One-Way Moving Platform
sprite.notes: This platform moves in the specified direction when a player stands on it.

value.title: Triggering Event ID
value.comment: If Event Activated is set, the platform will be shown when this Event ID is activated.

value.title: Unknown Value 5
value.comment: 0 or 1. This is used in the final battle. No visible change.

value.title: Distance Traveled
value.comment: 0 = unlimited, 1 = 14 blocks, 2-15 = (16 x value) blocks

checkbox.title: Bowser Boss Battle Platform
checkbox.comment: Instead of the normal model, a texture from boss_koopa_lift.arc will be used. Replacing this model will result in custom textures for the platform.

value.title: Z-Order (Place Behind Other Sprites)
value.comment: Use this to make the platform appear behind other sprites or other identical platforms.

value.title: Width
value.comment: (Value + 1) x 2; Minimum size is 6 blocks.

sprite.name: Rotating Bill Blaster
sprite.notes: Joietyfull64: 'The Rotating Bill Blaster has some functions that accept 1-bit values, where each bit has a state of 0 or 1. ... This sprite has many functions involving and requiring random values. It also needs to remember the state and position of launched Bullet Bills and further adjust the shooting rate. 1-bit values make this sprite more versatile and all of the above possible.'

checkbox.title: Randomise Spawn Delay
checkbox.comment: Makes each individual cannon use a different delay.

checkbox.title: Shoot when Offscreen
checkbox.comment: Shoots even when the cannon is not onscreen

value.title: Number of Pieces
value.comment: Value + 1, Maximum 8 (0-7). Determines the number of pieces in the Rotating Bill Blaster (cannon pieces plus rotating pivots). The lowest piece will appear at the sprite's placement.

multibox.title: Rotating Cannon
multibox.comment: Each checkbox will cause the piece type to change from a cannon to a rotating pivot.

multibox.title: Rotates Clockwise
multibox.comment: Determines if each piece will rotate clockwise or counter-clockwise (from a hypothetical top-down view). Clockwise means that the piece will rotate from right to left 'around the front'. Pieces that rotate counter-clockwise will move 'around the back' from right to left.

sprite.name: Skewer - Down
sprite.notes: 2 models inside arc, one is normal, other is long (100+ blocks long). First model is probably used by sprites 137 and 140-142. The second model, for sprites 398 and 399.

value.title: Timing Offset
value.comment: Needs to be reverse-engineered for exact details. Changes the timing of the launch in relation to others. Likely synchronized to other skewers with same value.

list.title: Travel Distance
list.comment: Values marked with an asterisk (*) cause the skewer to disappear.

checkbox.title: Make Sparks
checkbox.comment: The skewer will make sparks when it finishes launching. Should not be used if the skewer will stop in midair. With two skewers touching each other, only one should have this checked.

checkbox.title: Silver
checkbox.comment: The skewer will be silver if checked, otherwise black.

checkbox.title: No Sound
checkbox.comment: If checked, the skewer will not produce sound. Nintendo uses this when two skewers meet with each other.

value.title: Delay Before Launch
value.comment: Delay value before the skewer shoots out in its direction

value.title: Delay Before Return
value.comment: Delay value before the skewer returns to its starting position

sprite.name: Water
sprite.notes:
Place this in the level to generate water. There are many different ways to use this type of Water.

Underwater Zone: If you just want to create an underwater zone, check Flat Top and leave everything else blank. Then place the Water about 6 blocks above your upper Zone boundary.

Line of Water: If you want water decorating the bottom of you level, put the Water anywhere along the horizontal line you want it to appear at. Again, do not change any settings.

Location Water: If you assign a Location ID, you can cause water to appear only within the chosen Location instead of across the entire stage.

Moving Water: You can also create water that rises and/or falls. This gets a little complicated, so be sure to read the related settings.

dependency.notes: When using Moving Water, the Water becomes loaded across the entire Area instead of just the active Zone. Please build your levels with this in mind. Additionally, do not use more than one Moving Water in the same Area as only the top (highest Y-Axis) one will take effect. If you need Moving Water in multiple Zones within the same area, use [253] Rising and Falling Water instead. Also, be sure to clear your Raw Data if you switch between different setting groups of Moving Water or Location Water to prevent unusual bugs and behavior.

list.title: Moving Water - Rising Speed
list.comment: This determines the speed at which the Water will rise, or rise and fall.

list.title: Moving Water - Falling Speed
list.comment: This determines the speed at which the Water will fall.

list.title: I wouldn't do that if I were you...
list.comment: Right now, you've selected [Extremely Buggy]. You've made a terrible mistake somewhere and have combined the wrong settings.
list.comment2: Please don't try to set Distance or Delays while using Falling Water. You will not like the results. Please trust me.
list.advancedcomment: Oh, so you turned on Advanced, did you? You think you're so smart... Well fine, I'll share the limited documentation we have on why you shouldn't use these settings: Falling Water works in a peculiar way. When the appropriate event has not been activated, or there is no corresponding event, [Never ON] then the water surface will appear [Distance] blocks higher. The water will then sink this many blocks, respecting any delays. After waiting for the delay at the bottom, the water surface will not rise again. Not exactly. Instead, it will 'skip' the rising part and 'jump' to immediately to the top. Additionally, using this with events will cause the water to rise, instead of falling. [ON] But the starting point is the same higher distance. The difference is that the water rises continuously as long as the event is enabled. [Endless Rising] If it is disabled, [OFF after ON] the water surface will 'jump' back to where it started and remain there until the event is re-enabled. [Why bother?] Additionally, 1-5 on Movement Speed values have some additional odd glitchiness. Supposedly. So please, stop trying to combine settings like this. Or your level will suck.

checkbox.title: Rising Forever
checkbox.comment: This determines which direction the Water will move.

checkbox.title: Rising Forever while On
checkbox.comment: This determines which direction the Water will move while the Triggering Event is activated.

checkbox.title: Automatically Rising and Falling
checkbox.comment: The Water will automatically rise and fall in accordance with the set delays.

checkbox.title: Rises Distance while On, Falls when Off
checkbox.comment: The Water will rise the Distance value once activated, and stay at the top until the Triggering Event is deactivated. If the Triggering Event is deactivated before it rises the full distance, it will finish rising, then immediately start to fall.
checkbox.comment2: This option only applies if Delay values are both set to 0, Distance is set, and Triggering ID is set. Do not use [Extremely Buggy]. No really, don't. It won't help you any.

checkbox.title: Rising and Falling while On, Glitch-Returns when Off
checkbox.comment: The Water will rise and fall in accordance with the set delays while the Triggering Event is activated.
checkbox.comment2: When the Triggering Event is deactivated, the Water will immediately return to its starting position in a glitchy manner. It is highly recommended to not cause this to happen in your level design. Use Event Chainers with Delays or the Event Looper to get this type of timing instead.

value.title: Moving Water - Distance
value.comment: This determines how many blocks the Water will move.
value.comment2: Setting this will drastically change the function of Moving Water. Please keep this in mind.

value.title: I really wouldn't do that if I were you...
value.comment: This determines how many blocks the Water will move. Normally. But you are a bad person and are trying to set combinations of options that are known not to work. So stop right there and either change this back to zero, or select the option to the left of where it says [Extremely Buggy].

value.title: Moving Water - Delay at Top
value.comment: This determines the delay when the Water has finished rising.

value.title: Moving Water - Delay at Bottom
value.comment: This determines the delay when the Water has returned to its starting position.
value.comment2: The initial delay only can be set by using event-controlled Water. Utilize Event Chainers to fake the delay settings if you need to set an initial delay.

value.title: Moving Water - Triggering Event ID
value.comment: The Moving Water mode will be triggered when this Event is activated.
value.comment2: Maximum usable value for this sprite is 64.

value.title: Location Water - Location ID
value.comment: Match with a Location ID to set a specific area in which to display Water.
value.comment2: Note that some sprites only work correctly in Non-Location Water.
value.advancedcomment: Location Water only works properly with Location IDs 0-127. Location IDs 128-255 will cause the Water to constantly move up and down slightly. It's unknown if a use can be found for this, so it remains documented here in the Advanced Comment.

checkbox.title: Underwater Zone - Flat Top
checkbox.comment: It is suggested to enable this when creating a fully underwater zone.
checkbox.comment2: We're not too sure why this would be important, since it cannot be seen, but Nintendo will always have this checked, so you should do it, too.

checkbox.title: Location Water - Flat Top
checkbox.comment: When enabled, the animated crest effect on the top portion of the Water is removed. This creates a 'square' look.
checkbox.comment2: It's recommended to only use this when the Water is touching a straight ceiling.

checkbox.title: Location Water - Place Behind Layer 0
checkbox.comment: When enabled, the Z-Order of the water will be moved slightly so that it appears behind Layer 0 terrain.
checkbox.comment2: In order for this to work properly, the visibility settings for the Zone must be set to 'Normal'.

sprite.name: Lava
sprite.notes:
Same settings as water. It can definitely be tricked by events to bring the lava surface back to the starting point (except probably mode 9+).

It's also possible to get rising / falling lava involving locations. If Mario or an enemy is touching a location, the lava will fall. It will then rise back up again when Mario/enemy leaves the location.

Furthermore, the lava can also automatically rise the specified number of blocks up and down with self-defined delay periods, regardless of locations. This works by switching the Event ID on and off in the right intervals. If the given Event ID is activated, the lava will rise the given number of blocks. If the Event ID is deactivated, the lava will fall again, but only if it has already reached the end of its Rising / Falling distance. Through an event system with at least 4 event controllers it is therefore possible to build a system that activates and deactivates the given Event ID indefinitely. A correct duration must of course be set for the event controllers.

Yoshi does not work or interact with this sprite.

list.title: Mode
list.comment:
The same options as water and poisoned water.

Tip: Unfortunately, this option does not work properly. It has some flaws. The main problem is that this option only works in ONE zone, while affecting all lava sprites in this zone. If a second sprite is used in another zone with a greater Y-value, the lower zone will be completely filled with lava.

All values marked with an asterisk (*) work in a particular way: When the appropriate event has not been activated, or there is no corresponding event, then the lava surface will appear higher. This can be set with the option 'Distance'. The lava will then sink this many blocks, respecting the delay. After waiting for the delay at the bottom, the lava surface will not rise again, but instead 'skip' the rising part and 'jump' to the top.

Using this with events will cause the lava to rise, instead of falling. But the starting point is the same as with the sinking behavior. The difference is that the lava rises continuously as long as the event is enabled. If it is disabled, the lava surface will be right back where the lava has started to rise and remain there until the event is re-enabled.

Using sprites with and without an asterisk (*) together (and both have 'Distance' set) in the same zone could cause the game to CRASH!!

checkbox.title: Falling
checkbox.comment:
The lava behaves normally if this box is not selected. By selecting this checkbox, a value of 8-15 for the Falling / Rising rate is used.
More information about the 'Falling' mode is also available in the Notes section and the notes for the 'Mode' option.

value.title: Delay at Bottom
value.comment: How long the lava stops after rising.

value.title: Delay at Top
value.comment: How long the lava stops after falling. Initial delay only can be set by using event-controlled lava. Simply use an Event Chainer sprite which triggers the lava movement after a specific amount of time.

value.title: Distance
value.comment: Amount of blocks the lava will rise.

checkbox.title: Flat Top
checkbox.comment: Checking this removes the animated crest effect on the top portion of the sprite. Creates a 'square' look. Recommended use only with a straight ceiling.

checkbox.title: Place behind Layer 0
checkbox.comment: Alters the Z-order slightly. Only affects location-based lava. In order for this to work properly, the zone must be set to "Normal" in the visibility settings.

value.title: Location ID
value.comment:
Match with a location to set the area of this sprite. Only works with Location IDs 0-127. Location IDs 128-255 will cause the lava to constantly move up and down slightly.
Please note, setting this value to 0 will produce so-called 'non-location-based lava'.
Setting it to any other value will create 'location-based lava'. Both have unique features. Location-based lava can alter its Z-index, thus appearing behind other sprites or objects. Etc.

value.title: Triggering Event ID
value.comment: When an object with this Event ID is activated (usually a Red Ring), this coin will appear.

value.title: Set ID
value.comment: If you have multiple sets of red coins in a level, each set must have a unique ID or they will not be counted properly.

sprite.name: Floating Barrel
sprite.notes:
Place this on water for the barrel to float. Can also float on lava and poison water.

Yoshi does not work or interact with this sprite.

checkbox.title: Initially submerged
checkbox.comment: Makes the barrel load in a bit submerged.

value.title: Unknown ID
value.comment: 0 or 1. Used as 1 in 2-04 A2. No related event; unknown use.

value.title: Movement ID
value.comment: Link to Movement Controllers to make this sprite move with them.

list.title: Related to Movement ID
list.comment: Set to the type of sprite you are linking the coin with. One value might be reserved for the unused Coin Cheep.

value.title: Unknown Value 8
value.comment: Always 0?

list.title: Z-Order
list.comment: 0, 1 or 2. Used as 1 in 4-24 A1. In that level, it places the coin behind fences. Used as 2 in 3-21 A1.

list.title: Type
list.comment:
Some coin types don't work together with a Movement Controller.

0 - A normal coin.
1 - Drifts horizontally in Mario's direction, inside a bubble.
2 - Sinks quickly in Mario's direction, inside a bubble.
3 - A loose coin, similar to those created when Mario kills an enemy with a Fire Flower.
4 - Sinks slowly in Mario's direction, inside a bubble.
5 - A loose coin, similar to those created when Mario kills an enemy with a Fire Flower. (May differ from 3?)
6 - Makes the bonus sound from a 10-Coin block bonus when the coin loads
7 - Floats upwards in Mario's direction
8 - Spins faster than a normal coin (?)
9 - Collected automatically when the coin loads
10 - Unknown effect, coin does not show.
11 - A loose coin that seems to fall from the sky
12 - A loose coin, similar to those created when Mario kills an enemy with a Fire Flower. (May differ from 3?)
13 - Unknown effect, coin does not show.
14 - Spins much faster than a normal coin
(does not show in non-location-based water)
15 - Frozen inside of an ice block (can be melted by fireballs).

checkbox.title: Remember Position
checkbox.comment: Check this to have the game remember where you move the springboard to, even if it happens to go offscreen.

checkbox.title: NSMBDS-style Positioning
checkbox.comment: Shifts the spring half a tile to the right. It is actually a leftover from NSMBDS, wherein sprites snapped to the the same guidelines as blocks. So they had to have those shifted values.

sprite.name: Rotation Controller - Spinning
sprite.notes: Rotates sprites with a matching Rotation ID.

list.title: Starting Rotation
list.comment:
No Starting Rotation at 0. This value sets an initial rotation for any matched sprite. It will shift the sprite 22.5° per value.
For coins and blocks, the Starting Rotation value is doubled - therefore, 4 = 180°.

list.title: Rotation Distance
list.comment:
No movement at 0. This is a distance value that sets how large its rotation distance is. It will move 22.5° per value.
For coins and blocks, the Rotation Distance value is doubled - therefore, 4 = 180°.

list.title: Rotation Speed
list.comment: 0-7. No movement at 0. These values ​​assume a uniform radius. The greater the radius, the faster the rotation speed. The rate of increase per values is very small. Values repeat from 8-15.

list.title: Starts Already Spinning
list.comment: (S) 0-3. Value 2 used in 02-24, A4 Z2 in combination with value 8 for nybble 10. It didn't perform it's function there, though.

checkbox.title: Clockwise
checkbox.comment: Spins counter-clockwise if not checked.

list.title: Effect
list.comment:
Makes a noise or effect when spinning.

Values 4+ : Value 8 used in 02-24 A4 Z2 in combination with value 2 for nybble 8. It didn't perform it's function there, though. This is a weird value that needs more testing. Seems to set a zoom minimum at the start and when it has turned 180 degrees. The further the rotating object is from one of those 2 zoom minimums, the more the screen zooms out. This effect remains, even if the rotating object doesn't exist anymore (it's broken (in the case of brick blocks) before the rotation starts), or if it's out of the screen. Smallest zoom: Zoom level 0 (24.75x14 blocks), Biggest zoom: Zoom level 4 (49.75x28 blocks). The rotation will continue forever, and the rotating object CANNOT be broken (brick blocks) or collected (coins).

value.title: Rotation ID
value.comment: Match this with Rotation-Controlled items to make them move.

sprite.name: (Unused) Jumping Cheep Cheep
sprite.notes: Only value is nybble 12. If frozen by ice, only half of the Cheep Cheep will be covered by ice; the other part will stick out.

value.title: Movement Style
value.comment: When set to 1, it looks as if the Cheep Cheep is 'stuck' in the water.

sprite.name: (Unused) En_Blur
sprite.notes: No code.

sprite.name: (Unused) "?" Switch (Orange)
sprite.notes:
Sprite creates a "Big" version of the normal orange switch, but in reality is no different than the regular orange switch. Probably was planned to be the final boss fight switch.
Note that it will CRASH the game if the level doesn't contain any other switch object!

value.title: Triggering Event ID
value.comment: If this ID is set, the switch will only show while this Event ID is activated. Slightly buggy if used with Multi-Use.

checkbox.title: Falls
checkbox.comment: If this is checked, the switch will be movable by environment stuff, such as dropping down when bricks below it are destroyed, or riding along a conveyor belt.

checkbox.title: Loads at Midway
checkbox.comment: If this is checked, the switch will only show if the level has been started from a midway point.

checkbox.title: No Music Interrupt
checkbox.comment: If this is checked, the music will not be interrupted when the switch is pressed.

list.title: Delay on Multi-Use
list.comment: This will set how long the switch takes to pop up after the timer expires on a Multi-Use switch.

checkbox.title: Upside-Down
checkbox.comment: If this is checked, the switch will be facing down. Upside-down switches cannot fall.

value.title: Respawn Delay
value.comment: Determines how long will it take for the Porcupuffer to respawn after being killed.

value.title: Spawn Delay
value.comment: Determines how long the first appearance on the screen is delayed.

value.title: Location ID
value.comment: Respawns and chases Mario only while he is in this location.

value.title: Movement ID
value.comment: Known matchedsSprites - 236 (required)

list.title: Non-Timed Event
list.comment: This sets whether the triggered event is timed or permanent.

checkbox.title: Place Behind Other Sprites
checkbox.comment: This will also place it behind the line itself.

list.title: Speed
list.comment: Sprites 106 (Line Controlled Moving Platform), 108 (Line Controlled Amps) 155 (Line Controlled Star Coin), 343 (Fuzzy), 402 (Line Controlled ?-Block), and 403 (Line Controlled Brick Block) have identical speeds.

checkbox.title: Counter-Clockwise
checkbox.comment: The Star Coin moves clockwise if unchecked.

value.title: Target Event ID
value.comment: Can trigger anything, but is usually used to trigger red coins.

value.title: Unknown Value 10
value.comment: 0, 1, No visual or functional change.

list.title: Item Reward
list.comment: Determines what power-up you get after collecting 8 coins. If you already have that power-up, you get a 1-Up.

value.title: Set ID
value.comment: Match to the red coin's Set ID to assign the rewarded item to that set of red coins. Usage of 0 is not recommended.

sprite.name: (Unused) Giant Breakable Brick Block
sprite.notes: No matter what is inside, this light-colored 3x3 brick block always breaks open. It can even be broken by small Mario.

value.title: Withstands (Needs Multiple Hits)
value.comment: Determines the number of hits/ground-pounds needed for the block to break. For this function, a texture will be used that has some odd-looking white numbers on it.

sprite.name: Fire Snake
sprite.notes: Yoshi can't safely jump on this enemy. A fireball will be made if Yoshi spits out this enemy.

checkbox.title: Unknown Flag 11
checkbox.comment: No visible change.

checkbox.title: (Unused) Hides
checkbox.comment: If this is checked, it will be a stationary ball of fire until you come close to it.

sprite.name: Movement Controller - Use Paths
sprite.notes: The distance of this sprite to the first node will be imitated by path-controlled objects with their Movement ID specified here. This means that every linked object will be placed the same amount of blocks away from each node, identical to the distance of this sprite to its first node. It is therefore recommended to place this sprite directly on top of the first node, so that all controlled objects follow the path directly as drawn.

value.title: Starting Node
value.comment: Determines the starting node for this path. If left at 0, the path will start from the beginning. This is not an actual node.

list.title: Mode
list.comment:
Changes the way the linked sprite behaves. Sprites controlled by modes 0 or 1 will keep their 'Moment of Inertia' between nodes, causing a 'hunting' movement. These modes effectively mix up speed/acceleration values from all the previous nodes.
Objects linked to modes 8 or 9 will use speed/acceleration values only from the previous node, causing a straight movement between nodes. Most of the time you will want to use 8 or 9. No movement at 2.

value.title: Movement ID
value.comment: Link with other Movement IDs to make those sprites move.

sprite.name: (Unused) Path Controlled Block Platform 2
sprite.notes: Works well, even though it's technically a test platform.

value.title: Height
value.comment: Large values may look ugly.

value.title: Width
value.comment: Large values may look ugly.

value.title: Movement ID
value.comment: Link with 159 in order to make it move.

value.title: At the End...
value.comment: When set to 1, it will jump to the node set in Nybble 10... but it seems to differ in this point from sprite 132. Still needs a list of options.

value.title: "Jump To" Node
value.comment: This is the nybble the platform will jump to when it reaches the end of the path.

sprite.name: Pipe Bubbles
sprite.notes: Pushes Mario away when underwater, and also pushes a 'spin-jumped' Propeller Mario. Also influences a normal spin jump.

value.title: Triggering Event ID
value.comment: Turns off when Event ID is activated. Setting this to 0 causes the pipe bubbles to be always activated.

sprite.name: Vertical Scroll Limit 1 (Left)
sprite.notes: This sprite allows you to limit how far the camera will scroll vertically. Place it on the (bottom or top) left side of the area you want to limit, and place an identical sprite 163 on the right side (same height). This will create an independent, vertical zone border located at the height of the sprite's placement.

checkbox.title: Revoke Vertical Scroll Limit (Left)
checkbox.comment: 0-15. 0 and 1 have no effect. Values 2+ seem to revoke the scroll limit.

list.title: Limit Side
list.comment: (S) 0-15. 0: The screen will stay above the scroll limit in all circumstances. 1: The screen will stay below the scroll limit in all circumstances.

checkbox.title: Permeable Scroll Limit
checkbox.comment:
(S) 0, 1. With this option, two new specific 'areas' are specified, above and below the scroll limit ('default area' and 'secret area'). Both areas touch the scroll border from the outside. If the bottom of a player's collision box leaves the original (default) area, the screen will quickly 'jump' to this new (secret) area. The shifting is independent of the height of the screen limit. The screen will be pushed up/down as far as needed, until the bottom of the screen is a certain number of blocks above/below the end of the original screen limit.
The required number of blocks between the bottom of the source region and the bottom of the screen is by default 5 (shifting upward) and 8 (for a downward shift). You can alter these values under 'Zone Settings' (Upper/Lower Bounds).
Shifting from the default area to the secret area above/below the scroll limit can be tweaked by changing values for 'Upper Bounds'. The opposite is true for 'Lower Bounds' (shifting from default area to the secret area below. The increase/decrease of the scrollable area reduces/enlarges the necessary distance to the same extent that is needed to pull off the shifting.

If Mario goes back to the default area, the screen will quickly follow and it will be locked to the default area as usual (unless Mario goes above/below the scroll limit once again to reach the secret area)...

This option can be used to set up secret zones that can only be seen if Mario reaches a specific position. This technique was used in many older Mario games, e.g. Super Mario Land 3: Wario Land. So if you are located below the screen, nothing happens. Only when jumping over the area, the screen scrolls up so you can hide secret paths there as you like. Similarly, one can also hide secret paths under the screen.

value.title: Unknown Value 10
value.comment: (S) 0-15. Independent of nybble 9.

value.title: Scroll Limit Shifting in Restricted Direction
value.comment:
0-15.
Determines how far the screen can scroll above/below the scroll limit (in blocks). Somewhat flawed if used together with 'Permeable Scroll Limit'. The position where the scrolling will begin does not differ from a scroll limit with shifting of 0. So it looks as if the screen is scrolling faster with increasing values ​​when Mario approaches it. Even higher values are canceled entirely and have no effect because the scrolling is no longer necessary when the end of the screen is too far above or below the end of the original screen border. Nevertheless, the screen jumps to the end of the scroll border when entering the default area again. Only if the bottom of the screen is too far beyond the original area (or vice versa), then the screen is already at the end of the scroll border, and no shifting of the screen is needed.

value.title: Unknown Value 12
value.comment: (S) 0-15. Independent of nybble 9.

sprite.name: Vertical Scroll Limit 1 (Right)
sprite.notes: This sprite allows you to limit how far the camera will scroll vertically. Place it on the (bottom or top) right side of the area you want to limit, and place an identical sprite 162 on the left side (same height). This will create an independent, vertical zone border located at the height of the sprite's placement.

checkbox.title: Revoke Vertical Scroll Limit (Right)
checkbox.comment: 0-15. 0 and 1 have no effect. Values 2+ seem to revoke the scroll limit.

list.title: Limit Side
list.comment: (S) 0-15. 0: The screen will stay above the scroll limit in all circumstances. 1: The screen will stay below the scroll limit in all circumstances.
